abstracts.cdata!:
The Seventh Power Project for Panama was
            approved on March 19, 1985. The project was initially
            delayed by the Bank's decision, in 1987, to suspend
            disbursements on all loans to Panama due to mounting
            arrears. Panama was experiencing a period of political
            turmoil and construction work was paralyzed for a long
            period of time. Subsequently, a disagreement arose between
            the Government and the Bank on the terms of renegotiation of
            the main cost-plus-fee civil works contract. Accordingly,
            the bulk (97.5 percent) of the loan was canceled. A study of
            medium-sized hydro-electric projects was successfully
            implemented. The project is not rated and no audit is
            planned. Project components were ultimately completed under
            local financing at a cost significantly higher than the
            original contract price. The performance of the consultants
            that carried out the feasibility studies was satisfactory.
            The performance of the Contractor for the civil works was
            tainted first by submitting an early claim for the works
            that they argued were not in the original specifications.
            The Borrower was affected by political and economic events
            outside its control. On balance, the Bank's performance
            was satisfactory and the decisions made were based on an
            exhaustive consideration of all the relevant factors. The
            Bank displayed considerable understanding in the initial
            phases of execution, assisted the Borrower, and examined the
            renegotiation thoroughly. However, the Bank might have
            prevented the cancellation if it had reacted more forcefully
            to the contract issues. The primary lessons learned are
            that: (i) during project preparation and appraisal, there
            should be clear agreement and understanding as to what
            constitutes appropriate procurement procedures, (ii) these
            procedures may not be changed without the Bank's
            concurrence; (iii) large construction contracts should
            always include appropriate price adjustment provisions to
            anticipate unforeseen project delays; and (iv) the Bank may
            best serve the interests of its borrowers by protecting the
            integrity of their procurement processes.
